thread.title: Lucas Duda makes Kevin Long, Terry Collins look like geniuses
thread.title_full: Lucas Duda makes Kevin Long, Terry Collins look like geniuses | New York Post

author: Kevin Kernan
title: Lucas Duda makes Kevin Long, Terry Collins look like geniuses
text:
CHICAGO — Get the foot down on time and bam.
That is the simple challenge for Lucas Duda and Wednesday night, the big man who was engulfed in a huge postseason slump, came through in a way that Terry Collins dreamed about.
Duda blasted a 420-foot three-run home run to center field at Wrigley Field in the first off Jason Hammel and then lined a two-run double to center in the second, sending the Mets to an 8-3 victory on Wednesday and a four-game sweep of the Cubs in the NLCS and onto the World Series for the first time since 2000.
“It’s pretty surreal,’’ Duda said in the house party that was the Mets clubhouse. “It’s a moment I am going to cherish forever. Just looking around the clubhouse and seeing these guys celebrate, it’s incredible.
“It’s a pretty special feeling. I’ve been blessed.’’
The Wrigley organist welcomed Duda to the plate with Camptown Races … Du-da. Du-da.
Travis d’Arnaud followed with another blast, giving the Mets only their second back-to-back postseason home runs in their history.
Of course, Daniel Murphy had to homer again (his seventh of the postseason) and did so in the eighth, a two-run shot.
Duda’s five RBIs tie the postseason franchise-record for a single game. It’s the fifth time it’s happened and second time this postseason. Curtis Granderson had five RBIs in Game 3 of the NLDS vs. Los Angeles.
It paid to have patience for the big man and hitting coaches Kevin Long and Pat Roessler deserve tremendous credit for bringing Duda along and getting him to hit for power when they needed it most.
“I knew Duda was close and he delivered tonight,’’ Long said. “The unique part of this team is that anybody can do it on any given day and today was Lucas Duda.’’
Long then smiled and said, “He just helped out Murph.
“For Lucas, that’s a big monkey off his back. The Dude wanted to contribute. The Dude wanted to be part of the fun, and he certainly was today. Five RBIs, I’m just so happy for him.’’
Duda came into the games at Wrigley in a 2-for-21 with those two hits being singles.
The wind was blowing out Wednesday to center field so Duda’s timing was perfect with his exaggerated leg kick.
The previously struggling first baseman said he was so relieved to come through and help his teammates and on this night he showed emotion on the field.
“It’s so nice to contribute,’’ he said as party master Juan Lagares poured beer on his head.
“I was pretty terrible for most of the postseason. To be in this position it’s an unbelievable experience,’’ Duda said.
“Working with Kevin Long and Pat Roessler they keep you positive. And Murphy is on a different planet.’’
Before spring training, Duda talked about getting to the postseason and having success.
“I think early we believed,’’ he said. “The young talent mixed with the older talent was huge.
“Having some faith in ourselves since Day 1 was huge. It’s been a long time since I contributed, but I think this all heads back to Daniel Murphy having the postseason he is having. Unbelievable. It’s incredible.’’
Collins has pushed all the right buttons and never lost faith in Duda, who hit .244 during the regular season with 27 home runs.
Duda was even more valuable to the Mets Wednesday night because Yoenis Cespedes had to leave the game with a sore left shoulder after striking out in the second inning.
“Honestly, these games weren’t that close,’’ Long said. “We did what we wanted to do offensively. I always said we have the ace in the hole and that’s our pitching staff.’’
For Duda, it’s all about finding a hitting rhythm and getting that foot down without having the head move too much. Collins said the key is staying “quiet’’ in the swing.
His .124 batting average was quiet coming into the game.
When all goes right for Duda the swing is quiet and the bat makes a lot of noise.
